ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Image processing, image filtering, cardiovascular systems, differential equation, all the different processes of convolution.
The course was well put together. You learned a lot about 1D and 2D signals. You really learn about Fourier and convolutions.

I learned how to create and observe schematic diagrams of the circulatory system in an effort to model it. I also learned how to apply differential equations concepts to image processing as well as the theory behind it.
I learned a lot about signaling and imaging I had previously not known. I have a very good understanding of the principles the class aimed to teach.

I learned how to analyze biological phenomena in a systematic manner. Wi learned to use Laplace transform methods to simplify and solve for impulse response functions. I developed an insight into how biomedical analysis is conducted using modeling.

In this course, I learned the fundamentals of analyzing signals (Fourier Transform, Laplace Analysis, etc.) and how to represent biological systems in terms of known models such as RLC circuits. Also, we covered the basics of image processing and modification.
Very good course for a bme prospect student, learn about biosignaling through applications

I learned how to analyze systems, particularly biological systems as a series of digital signals that are transformed to produce a particular output. This type of analysis allows for mathematical analysis and modeling of said systems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professors are soo kind but material is beyond dry and dull. The notes are scribbles and hard to follow. But the professors are the best!
A lot of material covered. Would love to see it summarized better with the higher yield material emphasized more. Was overwhlemd at times, but the professors and the TAs offered a lot of help.

I thought that the psets were rather fair and that the expectations for the midterm and final were also fair. However, I would have liked a little more guidance on how to approach MATLAB questions on PSETS, since a lot of them took much creativity to solve. Furthermore, if there was a living equation sheet that kept track of what we needed to know as the semester continued (ie, equations on flow). I found myself flipping through lecture notes just to find the relevant equations, and had they all been on a centralized location, it would've been much easier and conducive to learning.

The strengths of the class was the course style. The lectures made sense easy when we went over them. I liked the layout of the grading style. A weakness of the course is that I didnt really understand much of Duncans notes.

The strengths of the course include the homework, the TAs, the open-note exams, and the professors. One weakness of the course was the problem set due right after spring break, as it likely required work over break.

Strengths: TA's were very helpful and the weekly review sessions helped a lot with the homework, psets were based off class material

Weaknesses: I felt that the final exam covered some topics, particularly related to images, that we did not go into much detail on in class
Very cool having two professors teach the course! Was a good way to learn all the material, and the set up of the class helped with success

I wish the roadmap of the course and the connection of class material to real-world application was more explicitly stated. It took until the middle of the semester to synthesize the connection between the different mathematical tools we learned and the biological applications.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only take this if you have to

Not if the major doesn't require it. I feel like many of the students, myself included, was not as interested in the material as I would've liked to see. We jumped straight into many mathematical processes but seeing the real-life application would have made it better.
If you want to learn about Fourier and convolutions, then yes.
required

I would recommend this course if you want an introduction to approaching biological systems from an analytic and matlab-heavy perspective. The matlab content, however, was not directly taught and was primarily guided by TAs. Also, the course may seem repetitive at times, but the course is set up that way to hammer down on certain aspects in different contexts. Even if you dont like coding too much, this course may be rewarding from the various types of thinking introduced, such as using machine learning in image processing and considering the circulatory system as an electrical circuit.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are a biomedical engineering major. The course covers the fundamentals of signal acquisition and processing, and it is helpful to know.
I would recommend if required for your major
Yes. You gain an appreciation for how biological systems can be understood as signals. This helps with general comprehension of the workings of many biomedical devices and diagnostic tools.
